content: The Act titled "Scenic Columbia Gorge Restoration Act of 2017" allows for expedited recovery activities in response to catastrophic events in national scenic areas. The Act defines a catastrophic event as any natural disaster or fire, flood, or explosion. It also includes containment of the event before its actual end. The term "response activity" refers to salvage or reforestation operations following a catastrophic event in a National Scenic Area. The term "Area" refers to a designated National Scenic Area in the National Forest System. "Response activity" includes salvage or reforestation operations in a National Scenic Area impacted by a catastrophic event. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service. Within 30 days of a catastrophic event in a National Scenic Area, the Secretary of Agriculture must propose response activities for the affected lands. After completion of the process, the Secretary shall implement the response activity following an expedited environmental assessment. The Secretary must implement response activities in National Scenic Areas following an expedited environmental assessment, with a 60-day completion timeline after a catastrophic event. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 requires response activities in National Scenic Areas to be completed within 60 days after a catastrophic event. A categorical exclusion is available for response activities that do not exceed 10,000 acres and include lands visible from key viewing areas.
